annotation: Tie two pieces of cord together, cord (Fbg) - Ton loan ? - JCM
Means "to tie up firmly", for instance "to tie up a horse to a tree'

language: East Sumbanese, Umbu Ratu Nggai dialect

annotation: Tie up, wrap around, wind (as fishing line) (Bgs)

language: Kadazan Dusun of Taginambur, Kota Belud, Sabah, Malaysia

annotation: To wind, tie, as a cord in making a net (Ebt)

item: i seput - i koko lokon noos

annotation: 1. To tie up with a rope or string
2. To tie a knot in s.t; to tie two ropes together
3. To fasten s.t by tying; to bind s.t
lash; Bender et al. (2003) suggest that this form is an ancient doublet with yawyew.
fasten with rope as in making fence
fasten with rope as in making fence
fasten with strips as when fastening thatch rows for roof
fasten with strips as when fastening thatch rows for roof
(fasten, attach; close, a container with a lid)
Means 'to tie up', and in addition (in french) 'nouer, serrer
Ci < POc paqu-Ci '(1) lash together, (2) construct (house, canoe)'
Tie on around or up, tie a knot, bind, tether (Bse)
Bind, tie tightly round, tether, snare (in a noose) (Bse)
To tie, lash, as with sinnet
set an anchor, tie up a boat
set an anchor, tie up a boat
This lexical item seems to be the most typical one that conveys the meaning of 'to tie up, fasten'
This lexical item conveys two meaning 'to tie up' and 'to be agonizing'
Two coconuts tied together; tie in bunches
I don't know this form, but based on the structure <kubu> is probably the lexeme. <i kukubu> probably means 'he/she ties up/fastens' and <kubu ra kukubu> probably means 'tie/fasten the fastenings'.
Tied around, bound round to be
mpo- prefix. Note: there are MANY terms for tying; this is the most common response and is somewhat generic.
The distinction between those two lexical items is not clear
